entry.title: Netanyahu row casts doubt on Obama pledge to 'have Israel's back'
News24.com | Netanyahu signs first partners in new coalition
entry.summary: Jerusalem - Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu signed up his first partners on Wednesday for a new coalition government, a lawmaker and spokesperson said, putting him on course to lead a heavily right-leaning cabinet.

entry.title: Netanyahu sweeps past main challenger in Israeli election
entry.summary:
In the final days of campaigning, Netanyahu abandoned a commitment to negotiate a Palestinian state - the basis of more than two decades of Middle East peacemaking - and promised to go on building settlements on occupied land.

Likud said Netanyahu intended to form a new government within weeks, with negotiations already under way with the far-right pro-settler Jewish Home party led by Naftali Bennett, the centrist Kulanu party and ultra-Orthodox groups.

entry.title: Netanyahu signs first partners in new Israeli coalition
entry.summary: The deals with the ultra-Orthodox United Torah Judaism (UTJ) party and centrist Kulanu give Netanyahu's right-wing Likud control of 46 of parliament's 120 seats.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu facing new scandal over bloated expenses
entry.summary:
Netanyahu's allies angrily dismissed the allegations as part of a campaign to deflect attention from important national security issues.

In a statement, Netanyahu said he respected the findings of the comptroller and pledged to implement recommendations to curb wasteful spending.

"There is absolutely no indication of any assault on the public's integrity and certainly no indication of any criminal transgressions," he said.

entry.title: ?Netanyahu?s biggest fear? That Iran ?honors nuclear deal?
entry.summary: "Netanyahu said at the meeting that it would be impossible to catch the Iranians cheating simply because they will not break the agreement," one of the officials told Haaretz.

entry.title: Netanyahu to form next government after US spat
entry.summary: Several hours before Obama's remarks, the Wall Street Journal published a report in which US officials accused Israel of spying on nuclear negotiations with Iran aimed at reaching a deal that Netanyahu opposes.

entry.title: US-Israel ties sorely tested as Netanyahu's Congress speech draws near
Iran nuclear deal threatens Israel's existence, Benjamin Netanyahu tells President Obama
entry.summary: "This deal would legitimize Iran's nuclear programme, bolster Iran's economy and increase Iran's aggression and terror throughout the Middle East and beyond," Netanyahu said.

entry.title: U.S. to ?reassess? options following Netanyahu?s remarks
entry.summary: In a pre-election interview with an Israeli news site, Netanyahu answered "indeed" when asked directly whether there would be no Palestinian state if he were to win another term as prime minister.

entry.title: Israeli Arabs say they feel a greater sense of exclusion following Netanyahu election win
entry.summary:
Netanyahu has signaled he will set up a government of right-wing and religious parties.

Netanyahu, defending his record amid widespread criticism of his election-day remarks, told NBC that his government has spent "billions" in Arab towns to upgrade infrastructure and schools.

entry.title: Analysis: Why Netanyahu? It's more than just nationalism
entry.summary:
It's a mystery to many: Benjamin Netanyahu's campaign gained steam when he ruled out the creation of a Palestinian state, and he seems determined to continue settling occupied land with Jews.

The fact that Islamic State militants are menacing the region does not help, and was exploited by Netanyahu during a campaign in which he portrayed the militants in one TV ad as charging toward Jerusalem, with naive Israeli leftists even helpfully pointing the way.

entry.title: Israeli candidates on last day of campaign before election to determine Netanyahu's future
entry.summary:
Netanyahu, who has governed for the past six years and has long been the most dominant personality in Israeli politics, has watched his standing plummet in recent weeks.

As Netanyahu's poll numbers have dropped in recent days, he has appeared increasingly desperate, stepping up his nationalistic rhetoric in a series of interviews to local media to appeal to his core base.

Netanyahu has also complained of an international conspiracy to oust him, funded by wealthy foreigners who dislike him, and on Sunday night, he addressed an outdoor rally before tens of thousands of hard-line supporters in Tel Aviv.

Tuesday's election caps an acrimonious three-month campaign that is widely seen as a referendum on Netanyahu.

The hard-line leader has portrayed himself as the only politician capable of confronting Israel's numerous security challenges, while his opponents have focused on the country's high cost of living and presented Netanyahu as imperious and out of touch with the common man.

entry.title: Butt-injection convict tells paper she has Netanyahu crush
entry.summary: In them, Windslowe says she has a crush on Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and on her prosecutor.

entry.title: Barack Obama, Benjamin Netanyahu relationship frankly, transparently poisonous
entry.summary: The relationship between Benjamin Netanyahu and Barack Obama, the leader of his nation's most crucial ally, is now frankly, transparently, poisonous.

entry.title: Netanyahu presses U.S. to seek better deal on Iran
entry.summary: In appearances on U.S. television on Sunday, Netanyahu did not repeat his assertion on Friday that any final agreement should include a commitment by Iran recognizing Israel's right to exist.

entry.title: Majority winner Netanyahu apologises to Arab Israelis
entry.summary:
"His excuses are not acceptable because not only does Benjamin Netanyahu plan to bring in racist legislation but his words challenged the very right of Arab Israelis to vote for the Knesset," Israel's parliament, he said on television.

Netanyahu is expected to be formally handed the task of building a coalition government on Wednesday after securing the backing of a solid majority of MPs in the 120-seat Knesset.

entry.title: No Palestinian state while I am PM, says faltering Netanyahu
entry.summary:
"I think that anyone who moves to establish a Palestinian state and evacuate territory gives territory away to radical Islamist attacks against Israel," Mr Netanyahu told NRG.

"Netanyahu has done everything possible to bury the two-state solution," Palestine Liberation Organisation committee member Saeb Erekat said, adding that the Israeli prime minister's latest statement counted on "full impunity from the international community".

In 2009 - the election in which Mr Netanyahu took the prime ministership for a second time - the centrist Kadima party won the most seats but was unable to form a coalition and in the end, Mr Netanyahu took power.

entry.title: Netanyahu legacy on the line in Israeli vote
entry.summary: Despite Netanyahu's speech to Congress, his efforts to halt the Iranian nuclear program which he describes as the mission of his lifetime appear to be stumbling as the U.S. seems to move toward a deal with the Islamic Republic.

entry.title: Israeli premier says he offered 'practical alternative' to Iran deal in speech to US Congress
entry.summary:
In a statement released after he landed in Israel, Netanyahu said the alternative deal he presented in Congress would make it harder for Iran to build a nuclear bomb.

Wednesday night, a poll broadcast on Israel's Channel 10 showed Netanyahu's Likud party picking up two seats to 23, which puts it neck and neck with the dovish opposition, the Zionist Union.

entry.title: Kerry working on Iran nuke deal, Netanyahu to criticize it
entry.summary: The officials said earlier they expected the talks would resume and likely continue through Netanyahu's address to Congress, delivered in the late afternoon local time in Montreux.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu given 14 more days to form govt
Netanyahu receives two-week extension to form government
Despite Victory, Netanyahu Is Struggling To Form Coalition
Despite victory, Israeli PM Netanyahu struggling to form coalition
entry.summary: Herzog's only hint of common ground with Netanyahu was a position paper issued by his party that backed Netanyahu's opposition to the recent U.S.-led framework nuclear deal with Iran.

entry.title: Despite victory, Israeli leader struggling to form coalition
entry.summary:
But after weeks of negotiations with potential partners, Netanyahu is finding the task harder than expected and is flirting with the idea of reaching out to his main dovish rivals to form a unity government.

Throughout the heated campaign, Netanyahu ruled out the possibility of joining forces with Isaac Herzog and his center-left Zionist Union and vowed to rule from the right.

Netanyahu looks close to finalizing deals with two ultra-Orthodox parties, Shas and Yahadut Hatorah, who are seeking ministries and parliamentary committees with large budgets catering to their constituents.

But large gaps remain with the two other pieces needed to complete the puzzle, the nationalist Jewish Home and Yisrael Beiteinu parties, both of whom are led by long-time Netanyahu associates who have a tumultuous relationship with the boss.

Tsahi Hanegbi, the deputy foreign minister from Netanyahu's Likud Party, said the prospect of Herzog joining the coalition was only becoming a possibility due to the hard-ball approach of the right-wing parties.

entry.title: Iran must end 'aggression' for sanctions relief: Netanyahu
entry.summary:
But Netanyahu, whose government has repeatedly denounced the framework agreement as an "historic mistake", said any such move should be linked to other issues.

"To my regret, all of the things I warned about vis-a-vis the framework agreement that was put together in Lausanne are coming true before our eyes," Netanyahu's office quoted him as saying, referring to the Swiss city where the framework deal was agreed.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu says sanctions should remain on Iran
entry.summary:
Benjamin Netanyahu has harshly criticized the U.S.-led framework deal with Iran, which offers relief from sanctions in exchange for scaling back its suspect nuclear program.

Netanyahu said Sunday that a better deal would tie the lifting of all sanctions, "to an end of Iran's aggression in the region, its worldwide terrorism and its threats to annihilate Israel."

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu says sanctions should remain on Iran
Walker says he expects to meet with Netanyahu in Israel
entry.summary: Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker says he "absolutely" expects to meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu during his first visit to Israel next month.

entry.title: Walker says he expects to meet with Netanyahu in Israel
entry.summary: Walker said his goal is to meet with Netanyahu and other members of the Israeli government to get an understanding of the issues facing the Middle East.

entry.title: Walker says he expects to meet with Netanyahu during his 1st trip to Israel next month
entry.summary: Walker, a Republican, told The Associated Press in an interview ahead of his departure on a European trade mission that the Netanyahu meeting in mid-May is not yet confirmed, but that it's his "hope and expectation" it will happen.

entry.title: Netanyahu blasts Iran nuclear deal
entry.summary:
"It doesn't roll back Iran's nuclear program," Netanyahu told CNN, one of several US networks he appeared on to slam the deal Sunday.

Relations between Israel and its traditionally staunch US ally are at a low and were hugely damaged when Netanyahu took the unprecedented step of addressing Congress last month to attack the nuclear negotiations with Iran.

Israel's government reacted angrily to the historic agreement, which aims for a June 30 deadline for a final deal, with Netanyahu demanding that Iranian recognition of the Jewish state's right to exist be written into the agreement.

entry.title: Israel PM Benjamin Netanyahu seeks 'better deal' to curb Iran's nuclear plans
entry.summary:
Obama, whose relations with Netanyahu have frayed badly over the Iran issue, sought to assure Israelis he understands their concerns.

Obama told Netanyahu in a telephone call soon after the deal was reached that it represented progress toward a lasting solution that cuts off Iran's path to a nuclear weapon.

entry.title: Netanyahu: Nuke deal enables Iran "terror machine"
entry.summary: "[T]hat is: standing firm, ratcheting up the pressure, until you get a better deal," Netanyahu said.

entry.title: Netanyahu once again blasts Iran nuclear deal
entry.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday again denounced the agreement between Tehran and world powers as a "bad deal" that will strengthen Iran's military and leave it with a large nuclear infrastructure.

entry.title: Netanyahu presses U.S. to seek better deal on Iran
entry.summary:
Netanyahu said he has spoken with both Democrats and Republicans in Congress - nearly two thirds of House of Representatives members and a similar number in the U.S. Senate - about the Iran nuclear issue.

Appearing on CNN, Senator Dianne Feinstein, a leading Democratic voice on foreign affairs, said she did not believe the agreement threatened Israel, and had harsh words for Netanyahu.

Netanyahu denied he was coordinating with House of Representatives Speaker John Boehner, who visited Israel last week, and with other Republicans to block the Iran deal.

entry.title: Ethnic tensions between Israeli Jews fuel Netanyahu victory
entry.summary: This Wednesday, March 18, 2015 photo, shows Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu election campaign poster lying among ballot papers at his party's election headquarters in Tel Aviv.

entry.title: Ethnic tensions between Israeli Jews fuel Netanyahu victory
entry.summary: Netanyahu, whose hard-line rhetoric taps into Mizrahi disdain for the Arabs who mistreated them in their countries of origin, "speaks not only fluent English, but also fluent Mizrahi," wrote Avi Issacharoff in the Times of Israel website.

entry.title: Traditional Mizrahi vote for Netanyahu's Likud unleashes Israeli ethnic divide once again
entry.summary:
Mizrahi, or Middle Eastern, Jews heavily backed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud Party, while Ashkenazi, or European, Jews mostly identified with the opposition Zionist Union.

Since Netanyahu's win, the sides have been exchanging insults that have not been heard in public in a generation - with the Mizrahi voters accused of being primitive and Ashkenazi voters viewed as elitist.

They also often argue that Netanyahu's hard-line policies toward the Palestinians prevent a peace agreement that would bring on an economic boom that would benefit Mizrahim.

Yet voting patterns from this month's election indicate that Netanyahu largely owes his re-election to the last-minute mobilization of Likud's Mizrahi supporters.

entry.title: News24.com | Iran must recognise Israel's right to exist in final deal - Netanyahu
entry.summary: "Israel demands that any final agreement with Iran will include a clear and unambiguous Iranian commitment of Israel's right to exist," Netanyahu said in a statement.

entry.title: Netanyahu: Israel Cabinet strongly opposes Iran nuclear deal
entry.summary: Netanyahu said his Cabinet "is united strongly opposing the proposed deal," which he said would threaten Israel's survival.

entry.title: Netanyahu: Deal must 'significantly' curb Iran nuke program
entry.summary:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been a leading critic of the nuclear talks, which aim to curb Iran's suspect nuclear program.

Netanyahu has said he believes the deal, which must be finalized in the coming months, will leave too much of Iran's nuclear infrastructure intact.

"Any deal must significantly roll back Iran's nuclear capabilities and stop its terrorism and aggression," Netanyahu said on Twitter, minutes before the announcement from Lausanne.

entry.title: Netanyahu, Boehner hail 'strong' US, Israel ties
Lausanne deal would pave way for nuclear-armed Iran: Netanyahu
Disputes emerge as Netanyahu starts work on new Israel govt
entry.summary: Since the election, Netanyahu has sought to backtrack on his remarks on a Palestinian state, and issued a public apology to the Arab community.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu asked to form Israel's government
entry.summary: Israeli law does not oblige the president to assign the task of forming the government to the party that won the largest share of votes, in this case Mr Netanyahu's Likud.

entry.title: Netanyahu gets go-ahead to form Israel's next government
entry.summary:
JERUSALEM (Reuters) - Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, grappling with fierce White House disapproval, won consent from Israel's president on Wednesday to try to form a new coalition government.

Netanyahu's pre-election promise that there would be no Palestinian state on his watch and his comments about Arab voters further aggravated his testy relationship with U.S. President Barack Obama, who has dismissed his subsequent attempts to backtrack.

entry.title: Netanyahu gets go-ahead to form Israel's next government
entry.summary: President Reuven Rivlin had some uncharacteristic criticism of Netanyahu as he went through the formality of handing him a mandate to establish a new government, having verified with party leaders that a majority supported him.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu Takes Conciliatory Tone
entry.summary: Netanyahu also may defy expectations and invite moderate political opponents to join his government - a step that could help promote unity at home and blunt international criticism.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu takes conciliatory tone
entry.summary: Although his party does not control a majority, party leaders controlling a total of 67 seats recommended that Netanyahu lead the next government for what would be his third consecutive term.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu takes conciliatory tone
entry.summary:
Netanyahu's comments appeared to be aimed at repairing the damage caused by comments he made in the final days of the campaign that strained relations with the U.S. and drew accusations of racism from the country's Arab minority.

Netanyahu spoke at a ceremony where the country's president, Reuven Rivlin, officially handed him the task of forming the next government.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu takes conciliatory tone
entry.summary: Seeking to shore up support among his hard-line voters in the final hours of the campaign, Netanyahu said he would not allow the establishment of a Palestinian state on his watch and warned that Arab voters were heading to the polls "in droves."

entry.title: Netanyahu, Putin on same 'businesslike' level with Obama
entry.summary: Relations have cooled further since Netanyahu has been vocal in his criticism of the nuclear talks with Iran and since he declared that a Palestinian state would not be created as long as he was prime minister.

entry.title: Obama calls relations with Netanyahu 'businesslike,' same term used for Putin
entry.summary: WASHINGTON -- When it comes to relations with President Barack Obama, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been -- elevated is not quite the right word -- placed in rare company.

entry.title: Obama: Netanyahu statements don't clarify two-state solution
entry.summary: Obama noted a tendency in reporting to frame the current dispute as a personal issue between Netanyahu and Obama.

entry.title: Arab-Israeli Political Leaders Reject Netanyahu's Apology
entry.summary: Emilie Moatti, a spokeswoman for the Joint List, said the Arab dignitaries who gathered at Netanyahu's home where the apology was filmed were all Likud supporters, with no Joint List representatives invited.

entry.title: Arab-Israeli leaders reject Netanyahu's apology for offending Arabs in election-day comment
entry.summary: Arab-Israeli politician Ahmed Tibi told Israel Radio Tuesday that Netanyahu's attempt to defuse the dispute was "not an honest apology."

entry.title: Arab-Israeli political leaders reject Netanyahu's apology
Majority winner Netanyahu apologises to Arab Israelis
entry.summary: Netanyahu made a last-minute call to his supporters to vote last Tuesday in an attempt to counter a high turnout among Arabs.

entry.title: Top Obama aide: US can't ignore Netanyahu's comments
entry.summary:
On Monday, Netanyahu apologized to Israel's Arab citizens for another set of remarks that offended members of the community and drew additional U.S. criticism.

Obama's decision to dispatch his chief of staff to speak to J Street, just days after the election, was perceived as another sign that Obama intends to take a tougher tack toward Netanyahu despite his insistence that the U.S.-Israeli relationship is still strong.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu apologizes to country's Arab minority
entry.summary: But President Barack Obama's chief of staff, Denis McDonough, rejected Netanyahu's attempt to distance himself from his comments, telling an Israel advocacy group Monday that the U.S. can't just overlook what Netanyahu said on the eve of his re-election.

entry.title: Netanyahu tells Israel's Arabs he 'regrets' election-day rallying call
entry.summary:
JERUSALEM (Reuters) - Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Monday he regretted offending Israel's Arabs during a rallying call on election day last week that his critics had denounced as racist.

Speaking to the group of Israeli Arabs at his official residence in Jerusalem on Monday, Netanyahu said: "I consider myself as prime minister of each one of you, of all Israel's citizens, regardless of religion, race or gender."

entry.title: Netanyahu tells Israel's Arabs he "regrets" election-day rallying call
entry.summary: In a video clip posted on his Facebook page, Netanyahu told representatives of Israel's Arab community: "I know that the things I said a few days ago offended Israel's Arabs. I had no intention for this to happen, I regret this."

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu apologizes to country's Arab minority
entry.summary:
Netanyahu drew accusations of racism in Israel, especially from its Arab minority, and a White House rebuke when, just a few hours before polling stations were to close across the country, he warned that Arab citizens were voting "in droves."

Netanyahu, whose Likud Party won re-election in the vote, met with members of the Arab community at the prime minister's residence in Jerusalem on Monday and apologized.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu appears poised to build coalition
entry.summary: Rivlin is scheduled to meet with Netanyahu later this week and officially set the coalition talks into motion.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu appears poised to build coalition
entry.summary:
It became a formality after the new centrist party Kulanu gave its nod to Netanyahu as well, giving him 61 backers out of the 120 in parliament.

Netanyahu appears poised to set up a coalition with Kulanu and several religious and ultra-Orthodox parties.

entry.title: For liberal Israelis, Netanyahu's win is a reality check
entry.summary: But as the results trickled in on Wednesday, they showed Likud with a shocking lead that has all but guaranteed Netanyahu a third consecutive term.

entry.title: For Liberal Israelis, Netanyahu's Win Is a Reality Check
entry.summary: Social media was full of embittered Israelis accusing Netanyahu's supporters of racism, and some vowed to stop donating charity to the underprivileged whom they perceived as being automatic supporters of the right.

entry.title: For liberal Israelis, Netanyahu's win is a reality check
Boehner off to Israel; Netanyahu's ties to Obama hit new low
entry.summary: Obama called Netanyahu to congratulate him on his re-election, but also told the Israeli leader that the U.S. is reassessing its approach to Israeli-Palestinian peace in light of his comments about a Palestinian state.

entry.title: Boehner off to Israel; Netanyahu's Ties to Obama Hit New Low
entry.summary: House Speaker John Boehner is heading to Israel as already strained relations between the White House and newly re-elected Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu hit a new low this week.

entry.title: Israeli Arabs say they feel a greater sense of exclusion following Netanyahu election win
entry.summary: After initially trailing in opinion polls, Netanyahu's Likud Party did well in traditional strongholds, including working class towns with large numbers of Sephardic Jews of Middle Eastern descent.

entry.title: Israeli Arabs say they feel more excluded after election
entry.summary: The election, in which Netanyahu eventually secured his fourth term, highlighted the fraught relationship between Israel's Arab citizens and the Jewish state.

entry.title: Israeli Arabs say they feel more excluded after election
entry.summary:
In what was seen as an attempt to galvanize his hard-line supporters during Tuesday's election, Netanyahu had warned that "Arab voters are going in droves to the polls," with the help of "left-wing" activists.

Asked by NPR if he would engage in fence-mending, given how his remarks were received, Netanyahu said: "Well, I certainly will make sure that everybody understands that I'm the prime minister of all of Israel's citizens, and I really believe that. It's something that my actions have shown. It's not a question of fence-mending, it's a question of real belief, and it's there. I don't have to fabricate it."

entry.title: Obama congratulates Netanyahu on election in phone call
entry.summary: The call came as the White House continued to push back against Netanyahu's pre-election rejection of a two-state solution to Palestinian-Israeli peace.

entry.title: In Netanyahu call, Obama says US reassessing peace approach
entry.summary: But a White House official said Obama also raised Netanyahu's critical comments about Israeli Arabs ahead of the election, which the White House has denounced as a "cynical" effort to mobilize voters.

entry.title: Obama tells Netanyahu U.S. to "reassess" policy on Israel, Mideast diplomacy [Video]
entry.summary:
Obama's telephone call to Netanyahu followed a television interview in which the Israeli leader backed away from his pre-election declaration that there would be no Palestinian state on his watch, an about-face apparently aimed at quelling U.S. criticism triggered by his comments.

An official statement put out later in the day said Obama called Netanyahu to congratulate him on his election win and used the opportunity to reaffirm his commitment to a two-state solution, a longtime cornerstone of U.S. policy on the Middle East conflict.

entry.title: Obama tells Netanyahu U.S. to 'reassess' policy on Israel, Mideast diplomacy
entry.summary:
White House spokesman Josh Earnest warned earlier that there would be "consequences" for Israel as the Obama administration monitors the formation of Netanyahu's new ruling coalition.

The White House official said in the phone call Obama "also discussed Prime Minister Netanyahu's comments about Israeli Arabs" but gave no details.

entry.title: Netanyahu denies abandoning two-state solution
entry.summary: Speaking with NBC television, Netanyahu insisted he was "proud to be the prime minister of all Israeli citizens, Arabs and Jews alike" after triggering outrage for warning supporters that Israeli Arabs were "turning out in droves" to the polls.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu says still committed to Palestinian statehood if circumstances improve
entry.summary: JERUSALEM (AP) " Israel's Netanyahu says still committed to Palestinian statehood if circumstances improve.

entry.title: Analysis: Why Netanyahu? It's more than just nationalism
Centrist leader vows not to join Israeli government, accuses Netanyahu of racism
entry.summary: Isaac Herzog said his Zionist Union, which finished second in Tuesday's vote, would sit in the opposition as a counterweight to the nationalist right-wing governing coalition that Netanyahu is poised to form.

entry.title: U.S. rebukes Israel's victorious Netanyahu on Mideast policy
entry.summary: Netanyahu's insistence that there will be no Palestinian state while he holds office, seen as a maneuver to mobilize his right-wing base, angered the Palestinians and drew criticism from the United Nations and European governments.

entry.title: Israeli election results show victory for Netanyahu
entry.summary: Netanyahu's right-wing Likud Party scored a resounding victory in Israel's election, final results showed Wednesday, a stunning turnaround after a tight race that had put his lengthy rule in jeopardy.

entry.title: Netanyahu surges to victory in Israeli vote
entry.summary: White House spokesman Josh Earnest also said the U.S. would have to rethink the best way to bring about a two-state resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict - a cornerstone of U.S. Mideast policy for years - after Netanyahu rejected the idea.

entry.title: Netanyahu sweeps to surprise Israeli election win
entry.summary:
Benjamin Netanyahu swept to a stunning election victory on Wednesday, securing a third straight term for an Israeli leader who has deepened tensions with the Palestinians and infuriated key ally Washington.

After a close-fought campaign, Netanyahu's rightwing Likud party confounded expectations and won 30 of the 120 seats in parliament, against 24 for rivals the centre-left Zionist Union.

entry.title: Iran dismisses Netanyahu win, says nothing will change
entry.summary: Netanyahu swept to a stunning triumph, securing a third straight term despite a tenure of deepening tensions with the Palestinians and shaky relations with US President Barack Obama.

entry.title: Late returns give Netanyahu stunning victory in Israeli election after tight race
entry.summary: "Against all odds, we achieved a great victory for the Likud," Netanyahu told supporters at his election night headquarters, declaring victory even before final results were known.

entry.title: Netanyahu owes win to jitters over Iran-Gulf official
entry.summary: Netanyahu won an unexpected election victory on Wednesday after tacking hard to the right in late campaigning, including abandoning a commitment to negotiate a Palestinian state.

entry.title: Netanyahu claims victory in Israel election
entry.summary: With nearly all the votes counted, Mr Netanyahu's Likud party had won 30 seats in the 120-member Knesset, comfortably defeating the Zionist Union opposition on 24 seats, Israeli media said.

entry.title: News24.com | Netanyahu claims victory in knife-edge Israel vote
entry.summary: Figures published by public Channel 1 and private Channel 10 television both gave Netanyahu's Likud and Isaac Herzog's Zionist Union 27 seats each in the 120-member parliament.

entry.title: Netanyahu's Likud party leads in Israel vote count
entry.summary: Netanyahu had already claimed victory in Tuesday's election and the initial results seemed to ensure him a third straight term.

entry.title: Netanyahu claims victory in Israel election after hard right shift
entry.summary: Political commentators said Netanyahu seemed to have the easier path to forming a cabinet, with the support of traditional rightist allies - which would put him on course to becoming Israel's longest serving leader.

entry.title: AP ANALYSIS: Advantage Netanyahu in close race
entry.summary: Breaking away from Netanyahu's nationalist Likud two years ago after a falling out with the premier, he has adopted a vaguely centrist platform and flirted heavily with Herzog's Zionist Union.

entry.title: Despite tie, Netanyahu secures shot at 4th term as Israel PM
entry.summary: Israel's parliament election ended in a deadlock, according to TV exit polls, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seems to hold the advantage ahead of coalition talks.

entry.title: Netanyahu Urges Right-Wing Parties To Form Government 'Without Delay'
entry.summary: "Reality does not take a break," Netanyahu said in a speech to supporters after two television exit polls gave Likud a narrow lead over his center-left challenger in the ballot.

entry.title: Netanyahu's chief challenger, Zionist Union's Herzog, says 'everything open'
entry.summary:
TEL AVIV (Reuters) - Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's main challenger, Zionist Union chief Isaac Herzog, disputed Netanyahu's victory claim in Israel's election on Tuesday, saying "everything is open".

"This result allows us to return to power," Herzog told supporters at party headquarters in Tel Aviv after exit polls showed a tie between the center-left Zionist Union and Netanyahu's right-wing Likud.

entry.title: Israel election: Netanyahu and center-left Herzog tied in exit polls
entry.summary: "Against all odds: a great victory for Likud a great victory for the people of Israel," Mr. Netanyahu crowed on his official Twitter account on Tuesday.

entry.title: Netanyahu says no Palestinian state if reelected
entry.summary: Final opinion polls published late last week put the Zionist Union ahead with 25-26 seats with Netanyahu's Likud taking 20-22 in the 120-seat Knesset.

entry.title: As Israelis Vote, Netanyahu Rules out Palestinian State
entry.summary: Both Netanyahu and Herzog will now compete for a chance to form a coalition that commands a majority in the 120-seat parliament, a daunting task in Israel's fractured political landscape.

entry.title: As Israelis vote, Netanyahu rules out Palestinian state
entry.summary: His chief rival, Isaac Herzog of the Zionist Union, said he would make "every effort" to form a government, and an upstart centrist party led by a former Netanyahu ally-turned-rival was set to be the kingmaker.

entry.title: No Palestinian state while I am PM, says faltering Netanyahu
entry.summary:
In an election eve about-face, Benjamin Netanyahu has vowed there will never be a Palestinian state as long as he is prime minister, contradicting a previous commitment in a bid to woo wavering right-wing voters back to his Likud Party.

the centre-left coalition may win the most seats, but Mr Netanyahu's Likud may be able to form a coalition with the centrist Kulanu party, headed by former Likud minister Moshe Kahlon, and other parties to the right.

entry.title: Polls open in Israeli election as Netanyahu seeks fourth term, rules out Palestinian state
entry.summary: JERUSALEM (AP) " Polls open in Israeli election as Netanyahu seeks fourth term, rules out Palestinian state.

entry.title: Netanyahu promises no Palestinian state if re-elected
entry.summary: JERUSALEM - Embattled Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu pledged Monday that a Palestinian state will not be established if he is re-elected, as part of frantic last-minute campaigning ahead of parliamentary elections.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu says no Palestinian state if he remains PM
entry.summary: Netanyahu dissolved his government in December and ordered the new election, two years ahead of schedule, in the belief that he would cruise to a new term.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu plays the hardline settlement expansion card to capture right-wing voters
entry.summary:
they estimate the Zionist Union would win between 24 and 26 seats in the 120-seat Knesset, compared to 20-22 seats for Mr Netanyahu's Likud Party.

But it is not just voters who care about economic issues who have turned against the ruling Likud Party, it is also security experts who have despaired at Mr Netanyahu's insistence on focusing on Iran above all else.

"You and you alone turned the United States from an ally into an enemy," Shabtai Shavit, a former chief of the Mossad spy agency, said of Mr Netanyahu's actions, including his widely-condemned Iran speech to the US Congress earlier this month.

entry.title: Israel election: Benjamin Netanyahu may be on his way out
entry.summary:
Tel Aviv: In 1996, a canny and polished politician named Benjamin Netanyahu stormed onto the electoral scene and became Israel's youngest prime minister.

Soaring housing costs, in particular, became a prominent issue in this campaign, but Mr Netanyahu infuriated many voters by appearing to brush off their concerns in favour of a relentless focus on the Iranian nuclear threat.

entry.title: As Israelis prepare to vote, struggling Netanyahu puts legacy on the line in bid for 4th term
entry.summary: Peace efforts with the Palestinians made no headway during the past six years, and Netanyahu has backtracked from his earlier support for a Palestinian state.

entry.title: Netanyahu makes last attempt for rightwing vote at Tel Aviv rally
entry.summary: Kahlon, a former member of Netanyahu?s Likud party whose newly formed centrist party could be a deciding factor in who becomes prime minister, dismissed the offer as a pre-election stunt.

entry.title: Israel election: Netanyahu shifts tactics as Likud appears to slip
entry.summary: Jerusalem: When Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu made an unannounced visit this week to the Mahane Yehuda market here, he did not invite the local news media.

entry.title: Israel election: Netanyahu shifts tactics as Likud appears to slip
entry.summary: "If we do not close the gap in the next few days there is indeed a danger that Tzipi Livni and Bougie Herzog will be the next prime ministers," Mr Netanyahu told Israel's Channel 2 News, referring to Mr Herzog by his nickname.

entry.title: PM Netanyahu's party trails in polls before Israel election
entry.summary:
JERUSALEM (AP) - The last polls just days before Israel's election show Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud party trailing behind the center-left opposition.

Poll results in the Yediot Ahronot newspaper on Friday gave the Zionist Union, comprised of labor and a center-left party, 26 seats over 22 for Netanyahu's hawkish Likud party.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu claims 'worldwide' effort to defeat Likud as Israeli election looms
entry.summary:
A worker puts up a campaign poster of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Tel Aviv as Israelis prepare to go to the polls.

Jerusalem: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has told supporters there is "a tremendous effort, worldwide, to topple" him as Israelis head to the polls next week, according to an Army Radio broadcast.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu claims 'worldwide' effort to defeat Likud as Israeli election looms
entry.summary:
Little context was provided for the 12-second clip of Mr Netanyahu, speaking to activists in his Likud Party.

Mr Netanyahu, in turn, has been criticised in Israel and abroad for interfering in American politics by speaking about the Iranian nuclear program last week in the US Congress at the invitation of the Speaker of the House, a Republican, and against the wishes of the White House.

entry.title: Butt-injection convict tells paper she has Netanyahu crush
Tens of thousands call for Netanyahu to be replaced in Israeli election
entry.summary:
TEL AVIV, Israel -- Tens of thousands of Israelis are gathering at a Tel Aviv square under the banner "Israel wants change" and calling for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to be replaced in March 17 national elections.

The rally's keynote speaker is former Mossad chief Meir Dagan who recently slammed Netanyahu's conduct and called him "the person who has caused the greatest strategic damage to Israel."

entry.title: Former Mossad chief rejects parts of Netanyahu's Iran speech to Congress
entry.summary: Intelligence Minister Yuval Steinitz, of Netanyahu's Likud Party, told Channel 2 that he rejected many of Dagan's assertions.

entry.title: Speech fallout could determine Netanyahu?s fate
Netanyahu says he gave ?practical alternative? to Iran deal
entry.summary: In Israel, critics said the speech harmed Israel's strategic alliance with the United States and was aimed at drawing more voters for Netanyahu ahead of closely contested election on March 17.

entry.title: Netanyahu says he gave 'practical alternative' to Iran deal
entry.summary: U.S. President Barack Obama said the Israeli leader had offered no viable alternative to preventing Iran from getting nuclear weapons, saying "there was nothing new" in Netanyahu's speech Tuesday.

entry.title: After Benjamin Netanyahu warnings, US and Iran resume nuclear talks
entry.summary:
However, Mr Netanyahu's controversial speech to the US Congress on Tuesday, where he harshly criticised the diplomatic efforts to resolve the dispute, will make it harder for the Obama administration to sell the potential deal back home.

Mr Netanyahu argued that rather than preventing Iran from acquiring nuclear arms, a deal would "all but guarantee" that it would one day get the atomic bomb, putting Israel, the wider region and US interests at risk.

entry.title: Iran nuclear talks resume in Switzerland as Kerry meets Iranian FM after Netanyahu speech
entry.summary: The focus of his comments to reporters at the Swiss resort town of Montreux reflected U.S. concerns about the potential damage Netanyahu's speech could have on the negotiations by further empowering powerful Republican opponents in Congress.

entry.title: Fact check: 5 Netanyahu claims
entry.summary: CLAIM: Equating Iran with ISIS, Netanyahu said that "one calls itself the Islamic Republic. The other calls itself the Islamic State. Both want to impose a militant Islamic empire first on the region and then on the entire world."

entry.title: FACT CHECK: Did Netanyahu go too far in US speech?
entry.summary: NETANYAHU: "If Iran's intercontinental ballistic missile program is not part of the deal, and so far, Iran refuses to even put it on the negotiating table, well, Iran could have the means to deliver that nuclear arsenal to the far-reach corners of the Earth, including to every part of the United States."

entry.title: Netanyahu US speech impresses many Israelis, but not all
entry.summary: In Iran, which insists its nuclear programme is purely peaceful, foreign ministry spokeswoman Marzieh Afkham denounced Netanyahu's speech as "lie-spreading" and said it was "boring".

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu gives controversial speech to US congress
entry.summary: Mr Netanyahu was welcomed to the joint session of Congress with thunderous applause from Republican members, while over 50 Democrats - including six Jewish representatives - boycotted the address.

entry.title: No precedent for Netanyahu's contentious speech to Congress
entry.summary: In a speech that stirred political intrigue in two countries, Netanyahu told Congress that negotiations underway between Iran and the U.S. would "all but guarantee" that Tehran will get nuclear weapons, a step that the world must avoid at all costs.

entry.title: Netanyahu speech to Congress: Iran nuclear pact 'a very bad deal'
entry.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu speaks before a joint meeting of Congress on Capitol Hill in Washington, Tuesday, March 3, 2015.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu warns U.S. of 'nuclear nightmare'
entry.summary: In an appearance boycotted by dozens of Obama's fellow Democrats, Netanyahu said Iran's leadership was "as radical as ever" and could not be trusted and the deal being worked out by the United States and other world powers would not block Iran's way to a bomb "but paves its way to a bomb."

entry.title: Netanyahu to use Congress' bully pulpit to assail Iran talks
entry.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is seizing the bully pulpit of Congress to warn against trusting Iran to curb its nuclear ambitions.

entry.title: Netanyahu to use Congress' bully pulpit to assail Iran talks
entry.summary:
Two weeks ahead of voting in his own re-election back home, Netanyahu took the podium of the U.S. House where presidents often make major addresses, contending that any nuclear deal with Iran could threaten his nation's survival.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., did little to hide her unease and later issued a blistering statement criticizing what she called Netanyahu's condescension.

entry.title: Netanyahu to use Congress' bully pulpit to assail Iran talks

entry.title: Foreign talks to Congress often a yawn, but not Netanyahu's

entry.summary: "I deeply appreciate all that President Obama has done for Israel - security cooperation, intelligence sharing, support at the U.N. and much more," Netanyahu said.

entry.title: 'No disrespect' in Netanyahu speech

entry.title: Rhetoric eases but tensions remain as Netanyahu flies in to US

Netanyahu is expected to use his speech to urge Congress to approve new sanctions against Iran despite Obama's pledge to veto such legislation because it would jeopardize nuclear talks.

Speaking in Tehran on Saturday, Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif accused Netanyahu of trying to undermine the nuclear talks in order to distract from the Palestinians' unresolved bid for an independent state.

entry.title: Netanyahu in US, signs of easing of tensions over Iran speech
entry.summary: The United States and Israel showed signs of seeking to defuse tensions on Sunday ahead of a speech in Washington by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu when he will warn against a possible nuclear deal with Iran.

entry.title: Unwelcome mat: White House tries to counter Netanyahu visit

entry.summary: U.S. officials believe Netanyahu's trip to Washington is aimed primarily at derailing a nuclear deal with Iran, Obama's signature foreign policy objective.

entry.title: White House Looks To Undercut Netanyahu Speech
entry.summary:
The administration has already ruled out meetings between Netanyahu and Obama, saying it would be inappropriate for the two to meet so close to Israel's March 17 elections.

Congressional Republicans orchestrated Netanyahu's visit without consulting the White House or State Department, a move the Obama administration blasted as a break in diplomatic protocol.

entry.title: Unwelcome mat: White House tries to counter Netanyahu visit
entry.summary:
FILE - In this Oct. 1, 2014 file photo, President Barack Obama meets with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington.

President Barack Obama does not intend to be silent or out of sight when Netanyahu addresses Congress in a visit that was arranged by Speaker John Boehner behind the administration's back.

Administration officials have discarded the idea of President Barack Obama himself giving an Iran-related address to rebut the two speeches Netanyahu is to deliver during his early March visit.

entry.title: White House mulls how to counter Netanyahu on Iran
Netanyahu: Israel knows details of proposed U.S.-Iran deal
entry.summary: Benjamin Netanyahu's remarks come a day after the Obama administration said it is keeping some specifics from Israel because it fears the close U.S. ally has leaked sensitive information to try to scuttle the talks - and will continue to do so.

A former member of their housekeeping staff has filed a lawsuit claiming he was mistreated and verbally abused by Sara Netanyahu.

entry.title: European leaders reject Netanyahu?s calls for mass migration of Jews
entry.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Sunday that at a time of rising anti-Semitism in Europe, Israel is the only place where Jews can truly feel safe.

entry.title: News24.com | Israeli election chief curbs Netanyahu speech
entry.summary:
Overall, however, Netanyahu's Likud party remains marginally ahead, with most polls expecting it to win 24 or 25 seats in the 120-seat parliament, just ahead of the centre-left opposition.

Even if the centre-left wins, most analysts expect Netanyahu will be the only one able to form a workable coalition among right-wing and religious parties, allowing him to return as prime minister for a fourth term.

entry.title: Israeli election chief puts curbs on Netanyahu speech to Congress
entry.summary: President Barack Obama, at odds with Netanyahu over the Israeli prime minister's criticism of the nuclear talks, will not meet him during his visit, saying it is a breach of protocol to receive a foreign leader before an election.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu tells Europe's Jews Israel is home, Denmark rabbi says terror no reason to move
entry.summary:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu arrives to chair the weekly cabinet meeting at his Jerusalem office on Sunday.

"Jews have been murdered again on European soil only because they were Jews," Mr Netanyahu said.

But expressing the unease felt by many Jews abroad over such comments, Jair Melchior, Denmark's chief rabbi, said he was "disappointed" by Mr Netanyahu's call.

Shlomo Avineri, an Israeli professor of political science, described Mr Netanyahu's call as "an intellectual and moral mistake" and accused him of taking a populist stance for electoral purposes.

For some Israeli experts, though, Mr Netanyahu's call was a natural expression of the nation's ethos.
